specimenID.description: Identifying string linked to a particular sample or specimen

assay.description: The technology used to generate the data in this file

anyOf.description: Frequently referred to simply as HPLC, this form of column chromatography is used frequently in biochemistry. The analyte is forced through a column by liquid at high pressure, which decreases the time the separated components remain on the stationary phase.
An image recorded by a camera.

The Zeno walkway utilizes an advanced and patented electronic sensing array technology with a proprietary network interface to sense and deliver the position of two dimensional objects in contact with its surface.

A method which utilizes an experimental apparatus consisting of three arms all or any of which may or may not be enclosed, in the shape of a T upon which the test animal can walk. The maze may include doors which can be used to close off any of the arms of the maze. The maze is elevated a set distance, for example 40 to 60 centimeters, above the floor or platform upon which the apparatus sits.
assessment of mechanical nociception
health and location tracker

A method which utilizes an experimental apparatus consisting of four arms, usually two enclosed and two open, in the shape of a plus (+) upon which the test animal can walk. The maze is elevated a set distance, for example 40 to 60 centimeters, above the floor or platform upon which the apparatus sits.
A test utilizing an enclosure consisting of a single area bordered by clear or opaque walls, used to measure movement, exploratory behavior, etc of an experimental subject.

A method that utilizes a device consisting of a rotating rod the speed of which is mechanically driven and precisely controlled, for instance held constant or accelerated. The rotarod test is often used to measure riding time or endurance in order to evaluate balance, motor coordination or grip strength.
A mRNA profiling assay using digital molecular barcoding technology to quantify target mRNA molecules without the need for amplification.
An image analysis technique combining automated fluorescence microscopy with multi-parameter quantitative image analysis for the large scale study of cells (cellomics).
The branch of immunochemistry dealing with cells and cellular activity; the application of immunochemical techniques to cytochemistry.

An immunological procedure in which the antibodies are coupled with molecules which fluoresce under ultra violet (UV) light. This makes them particularly suitable for detection of specific antigens in tissues or on cells.
A radioactivity detection technique using X- ray film to visualize molecules or fragments of molecules that have been radioactively labeled.
A method in which electromagnetic radiation, in the form of light emission, is generated from an electrochemical reaction in a solution.
An application of PCR that measures the products generated during each cycle of the polymerase chain reaction process in order to determine the starting amount of template in the reaction.
A medical device that is a combination of ruler and caliper that can measure the distance between two points. The configuration of this device permits the measurement of internal dimensions.
An instrument or machine for weighing.
The determination of the measured concentrations of chemical constituents of the blood by assay in a clinical laboratory.
An imaging assay that allows detection of bioluminescence from a living organism or organisms.
An immunostaining assay to detect and potentially localize antigens within the cells of a tissue section
Nucleosome Occupancy and Methylome Sequencing
Flow injection analysis - tandem mass spectrometer
Ultra performance liquid chromatography - tandem mass spectrometer.
An analytical technique wherein high performance liquid chromatography is coupled to tandem mass spectrometry in order to separate, identify, and quantify substances in a sample.

A liquid chromatography method that is sensitive to compounds which can be either reduced or oxidised. The mobile phase passes directly over the working electrode, which is set to the specific potential required for oxidation or reduction. The current produced is then measured.
RNA Sequencing measurements
Small RNA measurements collected from RNA-Seq experiments

A method where a sample mixture is first separated by liquid chromatography before being ionised and characterised by mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance using two mass spectrometers in series
A method where a sample mixture is first separated by liquid chromatography before being converted into ions which are characterised by their mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance
Long non-coding RNA measurements collected from RNA-Seq experiments
Data derived from exome sequencing

A DNA sequencing technique in which a mixture of deoxynucleosidetriphosphates (dNTPs) and chain-terminating dNTPs, which are radioactively or fluorescently labeled, are combined within the reaction mixture. Once the reaction is complete, the DNA strands are separated by size, and the labeled chain terminating dNTPs can be read in sequence by the investigator or by a machine.
Chromatin immuno-precipitation followed by sequencing
RNA measurements captured by array technology
SNP measurements captured by array technology
Methylation data captured by array technology
microRNA measurements captured by array technology
Methylation data captured by sequencing of DNA treated by a bisulfite-based chemical process
Open chromatin regions measured by sequencing DNA after assay for transposase-accessible chromatin (ATAC) treatment
Chromatin interactions detected by HI-C protocol
Data for enriched reduced representation bisulfite sequencing data
Full isoform sequencing
Techniques that uses magnetic fields and radiowaves to form images, typically to investigate the anatomy and physiology of the human body.
A multistep process in which a mixture of proteins is separated by gel electrophoresis
Laboratory technique to sequence the complete DNA sequence of an organism's genome at a single time
A rapid technique for in vitro amplification of specific DNA or RNA sequences, allowing small quantities of short sequences to be analyzed without cloning
This assay type measures the cellular state of living or dying by measuring an indicator of life or death
Microscopy which uses a sharp spike (known as a 'tip') mounted on the end of a cantilever to scan the surface of the specimen
Microscopy where the specimen is illuminated with light transmitted from a source on the opposite side of the specimen from the objective
An experimental method for determining the tractions on the surface of a biological cell by obtaining measurements of the surrounding displacement field within an in vitro extracellular matrix (ECM)
A type of next generation sequencing in which specific genes or portions of genes are targeted for sequencing using amplicon-based workflow.
Kinomics assay using multiplexed kinase inhibitor beads and mass spectrometry (MIB/MS)

A method for genome-wide CpG island (CGI) methylation sequencing for single cells (scCGI-seq), combining methylation-sensitive restriction enzyme digestion and multiple displacement amplification for selective detection of methylated CGIs
MudPIT is a method for rapid and large-scale protein identification by multidimensional liquid chromatography associated with tandem mass spectrometry
A document with a set of printed or written questions with a choice of answers, devised for the purposes of a survey or statistical study.
Fluorescent imaging of linearly extended DNA molecules to probe information patterns along the molecules
Behavior related to the exploration/investigation of a novel object, situation or environment.
Avoidance learning when the action occurs.
An emotional behavior related to a feeling of uneasiness or nervousness triggered by an identifiable triggering stimulus.
Behavior related with the ability of an organism's ability to store, retain, and recall information and experiences.
Movement behavior of the body or its parts.
Activation of locomotory behavior.
Oxidative bisulfite sequencing (oxBS-Seq) to map 5-methylcytosine and 5-hydroxymethylcytosine
Ribosome profiling (Ribo-Seq).
A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue.
Reverse phase protein array (RPPA) is a an assay that measures multiple protein expression levels in a large number of biological samples simultaneously using high quality antibodies

A highly sensitive technique for detecting and measuring antigens or antibodies in a solution; the solution is run over a surface to which immobilized antibodies specific to the substance have been attached, and if the substance is present, it will bind to the antibody layer, and its presence is verified and visualized with an application of antibodies that have been tagged in some way.
Any measurable or observable characteristic related to the persistent robust synaptic response induced by synchronous stimulation of pre- and postsynaptic cells.

An extracellular electrophysiology assay where a microelectrode is placed in the extracellular space of brain tissue to measure action potential and compared to an electrode either outside or inside that tissue.

A patch-clamp assay where the electrode is left in place on the cell, as in cell-attached recordings, but the membrane patch has been perforated, providing access from the interior of the pipette to the intracellular space of the cell. Measurements made with this technique involve recording currents through multiple channels simultaneously, over the membrane of the entire cell.

The sandwich ELISA measures the amount of antigen between two layers of antibodies. The antigens to be measured must contain at least two antigenic sites, capable of binding to antibody, since at least two antibodies act in the sandwich. So sandwich assays are restricted to the quantitation of multivalent antigens such as proteins or polysaccharides. Sandwich ELISAs for quantitation of antigens are especially valuable when the concentration of antigens is low and/or they are contained in high concentrations of contaminating protein.

A noninvasive, non-scanning optical imaging technique that provides full-field visualization of blood flow to the tissue being imaged, which provides information about tissue perfusion and the efficiency of disease treatment.
The determination of the DNA sequence of an individual.

An isobaric labeling technique that uses tags containing four regions with the same total molecular weights and structure, so that during chromatographic or electrophoretic separation and in single MS mode, molecules labelled with different tags are indistinguishable.
A mass spectrometry assay that allows for measurement for endogenous targets in live cell assays, and eliminates the need for tags, dyes, or specialized reagents or engineered cells.

Single cell sequencing examines the sequence information from individual cells with optimized next generation sequencing (NGS) technologies, providing a higher resolution of cellular differences and a better understanding of the function of an individual cell in the context of its microenvironment.
The spontaneous alternation protocol is used to assess spatial working memory in mice.

Wheel running behavior in mice is a simple, easily quantifiable measure of behavior that can be assessed in the home cage and with little interruption.  Mice demonstrate age-dependent reductions in both distance and speed, and also time spent running, which may be an indicator of motivation.
A non-invasive characterization of aging-related changes in physical characteristics and reflexes aimed at assessing the onset of aging traits in individual mice.

dataSubtype.description: Further qualification of dataType, which may be used to indicate the state of processing of the data, aggregation of the data, or presence of metadata.

anyOf.description: A data set that is produced as the output of a normalization data transformation.
A file of data containing multiple values for multiple samples.
A data file produced by an instrument, or one with very little subsequent processing.
A file of data generated from running one or more bioinformatics methods on a raw file.
A file of clinical, technical, or other parameters that describe a dataset.

metadataType.description: For files of dataSubtype: metadata, a description of the type of metadata in the file.

anyOf.description: Metadata describing properties of individuals (human or animal) represented in the study.
Metadata describing properties of specimens collected and/or analyzed in the study.
Metadata describing properites of an assay conducted in the study.
Metadata describing terms or variables that appear in another file.
Metadata describing a list of files and the annotations terms associated with them.

A plan specification which has sufficient level of detail and quantitative information to communicate it between investigation agents, so that different investigation agents will reliably be able to independently reproduce the process.
The head is the anterior-most division of the body.

organ.description: A unique macroscopic (gross) anatomic structure that performs specific functions. It is composed of various tissues. An organ is part of an anatomic system or a body region.

anyOf.description: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule.
One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum.
The integument of an animal (as a fur-bearing mammal or a bird) separated from the body usually with its hair or feathers.
A specialized accessory gland of the skin of mammals that secretes milk. The gland is typically only developed in females, and regresses in males.

Any of the filamentous bands of nervous tissue that connect parts of the nervous system with the other organs, conduct nervous impulses, and are made up of axons and dendrites together with protective and supportive structures.
The portion of the vertebrate central nervous system that constitutes the organ of thought and neural coordination.
The fluid that circulates in the heart, arteries, capillaries, and veins of a vertebrate animal carrying nourishment and oxygen to and bringing away waste products from all parts of the body.
The fore or ventral part of the body between the neck and the abdomen.
The part of the large intestine that extends from the cecum to the rectum.
One of the usually paired compound saccular thoracic organs that constitute the basic respiratory organ of air-breathing vertebrates.
Lobular organ the parenchyma of which has as its parts glandular acini which are continuous with the prostatic part of the urethra.
A large lobulated gland of vertebrates that secretes digestive enzymes and the hormones insulin and glucagon.
One of the typically paired essential female reproductive organs that produce eggs and in vertebrates female sex hormones.

A highly vascular ductless organ that is located in the left abdominal region near the stomach or intestine of most vertebrates and is concerned with final destruction of red blood cells, filtration and storage of blood, and production of lymphocytes.
The soft, fatty, vascular tissue that fills most bone cavities and is the source of red blood cells and many white blood cells.
An epithelial outgrowth of lymphoid tissue in the cloaca of young birds, responsible for B-lymphocyte maturation. It undergoes atrophy and involution at six months of age.
A structure of special sense serving as an organ of the sense of smell and as an entrance to the respiratory tract.

The serumlike fluid that circulates through the ventricles of the brain, the cavity of the spinal cord, and the subarachnoid space, functioning in shock absorption. A liquid that is comparable to serum but contains less dissolved material, that is secreted from the blood into the lateral ventricles of the brain by the choroid plexus, circulates through the ventricles to the spaces between the meninges about the brain and spinal cord, and is resorbed into the blood through the subarachnoid sinuses, and that serves chiefly to maintain uniform pressure within the brain and spinal cord.

dataType.description: Types of input/output data in bioinformatics pipelines

anyOf.description: The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.
The vertical force exerted by a mass as a result of gravity.
A study of the process by which a drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and eliminated by the body.
Genomic alterations, including single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in a genome sequence.
The action, reaction, or performance of an organism in response to external or internal stimuli.
The systematic study of metabolites, the chemical processes they are involved, and the chemical fingerprints of specific cellular processes in a whole cell, tissue, organ or organism.
Biological or biomedical data that has been rendered into an image.
The analysis of levels and patterns of synthesis of gene products (proteins and functional RNA) including interpretation in functional terms of gene expression data.
Expression of protien isoforms formed from alternative splicings or other post-translational modifications of a single gene through RNA splicing mechanisms.
Protein and peptide identification, especially in the study of whole proteomes of organisms.
Kinomics is the study of protein kinases and protein kinase signaling.
Information on drug sensitivity and molecular markers of drug response
Information on drug sensitivity of more than one compound
Chromatin activity that allow access of condensed genomic DNA and potentially control gene expression.
A data set that contains the outcome of a survey.
An interconnected system of things or people.
Data obtained through patient examination or treatment.
Laboratory test involving interaction of antigens with specific antibodies.
Data generated from an electrophysiology assay.

individualIdSource.description: Database or repository to which individual ID maps

anyOf.description: Autism Brain Net
Advanced Biosciences Resources
Banner Sun Health Research Institute
Albert Einstein College of Medicine
Emory University
Harvard Brain Tissue Resource Center
The Jackson Laboratory
Lieber Institute for Brain Development

Novogenix Laboratories
The University of Pennsylvania Alzheimer's Disease Core Center (ADCC), Penn Udall Center and the Center for Neurodegenerative Disease Research (CNDR)
The University of Pittsburgh NIH NeuroBioBank Brain and Tissue Repository
Pritzker Neuropsychiatric Disorders Research Consortium Brain Bank
Rush Alzheimer's Disease Center
Sestan Lab, Yale School of Medicine
Stanley Medical Research Institute
StemExpress
Tourette Association of America
University of California - San Francisco
University of Maryland Brain and Tissue Bank
University of Washington Congenital Defects Lab
Yale School of Medicine

tissue.description: A tissue is a mereologically maximal collection of cells that together perform physiological function.

anyOf.description: A large nucleus in the thalamus. It receives inputs from the Pre-Frontal Cortex and the Limbic System and in turn relays them to the Pre-Frontal Association Cortex.

the middle division of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes a ventral part containing the cerebral peduncles and a dorsal tectum containing the corpora quadrigemina and that surrounds the aqueduct of Sylvius connecting the third and fourth ventricles.
The thin layer of gray matter on the surface of the cerebral hemisphere that develops from the telencephalon.
Frontal lobe is the anterior-most of five lobes of the cerebral hemisphere. It is bounded by the central sulcus on its posterior border and by the longitudinal cerebral fissure on its medial border.
A curved elongated ridge that extends over the floor of the descending horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain and consists of gray matter covered on the ventricular surface with white matter.
Portion of tissue in the nervous system which consists of neurons and glial cells, and may also contain parts of the vasculature.
Broadly-defined, consists of the lateral portions of Brodmann areas 9 - 12, of areas 45, 46, and the superior part of area 47.
That portion of the cingulate cortex which is located within the frontal lobe (the remainder being in the parietal lobe).

Component of the frontal lobe. The rostral and caudal boundaries of the frontal pole are the superior frontal gyrus and the rostral division of the middle frontal gyrus respectively (Christine Fennama-Notestine).

A long convolution on the medial surface of the temporal lobe, forming the lower part of the fornicate gyrus, extending from behind the splenium corporis callosi forward along the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus from which it is demarcated by the hippocampal fissure.

Component of the temporal lobe, lateral aspect. The rostral boundary is the rostral extent of the ssuperior temporal sulcus. The caudal boundary is the cauday portion of the superior temporal gyrus (posterior to becoming continuous with the supramarginal gyrus).

Component of the frontal lobe, lateral aspect. The rostral boundary is the first appearance of the inferior frontal sulcus whereas the caudal boundary is the precentral gyrus. The medial and lateral boundaries are the lateral bank of the inferior frontal sulcus and the medial bank of the lateral orbital sulcus and/or the circular insular sulcus respectively (Christein Fennema-Notestine).
Part of the metencephalon that lies in the posterior cranial fossa behind the brain stem.
One of the four regions of cortex in each cerebral hemisphere. It is located posterior to the temporal lobe and inferior to the parietal lobe.
The area of the occipital lobe of the cerebral cortex concerned with vision.

Component of the temporal lobe, lateral aspect. The rostral boundary is the rostral extent of the inferior temporal sulcus whereas the caudal boundary is designated as the temporo-occipital incisure on the cortical surface.

Component of the temporal lobe, lateral aspect. The rostral boundary is the rostral extent of the superior temporal sulcus whereas the caudal boundary is the temporo-occipital incisure on the cortical surface.
Component of the cingulate cortex. The rostral and caudal extent were the caudal anterior and the isthmus divisions of the cingulate cortex respectively.
Anterior component of the temporal lobe (rostral boundary) extends caudally to the entorhinal cortex.
Component of the frontal lobe. The appearance and disappearance of the central sulcus is the rostral and caudal boundaries of the precentral gyrus respectively.
A superficial feature of the parietal lobe that extends from the dorsal surface of the superior parietal lobule across the margin of the parietal lobe into the precuneus.
The prefrontal cortex is the anterior part of the frontal lobes of the brain, lying in front of the motor and premotor areas.
The one of the four basal ganglia in each cerebral hemisphere that is part of the limbic system and consists of an almond-shaped mass of gray matter in the anterior extremity of the temporal lobe.
Subcortical nucleus of telecephalic origin consisting of an elongated gray mass lying lateral to and bordering the lateral ventricle.
A region of the brain consisting of a collection of neurons located in the forebrain ventral to the caudate and putamen (caudoputamen in rodent).
Subcortical nucleus of telencephalic , which together with the caudate nucleus, forms the striatum.
Gray matter of the temporal region of the neocortex, located in the temporal lobe in gyrencephalic animals.
The region of the cerebral cortex covering the basal surface of the frontal lobes.
Is part of the prefrontal cortex, located on the inferior frontal gyrus, bounded superiorly by the inferior frontal sulcus and inferiorly by the lateral sulcus.

Component of the orbtial frontal cortex. The rostral boundary is the first slice where the medial orbital gyrus became visible whereas the caudal boundary is the disappearance of the medial orbital gyrus/gyrus rectus.
The part of the cerebral cortex that receives projections from the motor thalamus and which projects to motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord.
Gray matter of the parietal region of the neocortex, located in the parietal lobe of gyrencephalic animals.
The part of the auditory cortex that is located on the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe and receives point-to-point input from the ventral division of the medial geniculate complex.
A subdivision of the cytoarchitecturally defined occipital region of cerebral cortex in the human.
A region of the forebrain consisting of the caudate nucleus, putamen and fundus striati.
The superficial gray matter of the cerebellum. It consists of three layers, the stratum moleculare, stratum granulosum, and stratum purkinjense.
Liquid derived from blood plasma that has clotting factors removed.

Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.
Any leukocyte that is part of a spleen.
A fluid that is composed of blood plasma and erythrocytes.
A primary tumor is the tumor at the initial site of cancer, not where the cancer may have spread or metastasized, called the secondary tumor.
A portion of tissue that is part of an embryo.
The three thin layers of tissue that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord.
The most anterior region the brain including both the telencephalon and diencephalon.

Component of the orbtial frontal cortex. The rostral boundary is the first slice where the medial orbital gyrus became visible whereas the caudal boundary is the disappearance of the medial orbital gyrus/gyrus rectus.
The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) is composed of granular cortical areas (medial areas 9 and 10) and agranular regions (areas 24, 25, and 32)
Inferior Temporal (IT) Cortex is the cerebral cortex on the inferior convexity of the temporal lobe in primates including humans.
Component of the frontal lobe, lateral aspect
The outer neural tube region in which post-mitotic neuroblasts migrate along radial glia to form the adult cortical layers
VZ/SVZ (ventricular zone/subventricular zone) are proliferative transient zones situated near the surface of the cerebral lateral ventricles
Subdivision of pallium that is located dorsally
The soft, fatty, vascular tissue that fills most bone cavities and is the source of red blood cells and many white blood cells.
The mucosal membranes located on the inside of the cheek, in the buccal cavity.The inner lining of the cheeks.
Ganglion with sensory function within the vertebral column.
Unspecified tissue or tissues from an organ.
Brain tissue not limited to a specific region.
The middle layer of an anticoagulated blood specimen following separation by centrifugation. It contains most of the white blood cells and platelets.
Anterior portion of the neocortex, lying anterior to the central sulcus in humans. It is bounded by the parietal cortex posteriorly and the temporal cortex laterally
Composed of receptor and supporting cells and olfactory glands of Bowman, located in the superior part of the nasal cavities.

A distinct elevation of a transient proliferating cell mass of the fetal subventricular zone; this mass contributes most of its cells to the neocortex; however, hippocampal neurons, thalamus, septum and olfactory bulb neurons are also partly derived from the MGE.
insular cortex

individualID.description: Identifying string linked to the individual or animal being studied

platform.description: The specific version (manufacturer, model, etc.) of a technology that is used to carry out a laboratory or computational experiment.

anyOf.description: BGI DNBseq
Thermo Scientific Q Exactive
Thermo Scientific Q Exactive Plus
Illumina Novaseq 6000, high-throughput sequencing
Thermo Scientific Orbitrap Fusion
770 standardized genes covering 30 clinically derived AD-associated modules discovered in the AMP-AD consortium study of human brain tissue.
Illumina HiSeq 1000
Illumina HiSeq 3000
Illumina HiSeq 2500
Illumina HiSeq 4000
Illumina NextSeq 500
Illumina HiSeq 2000
Illumina MiSeq
Affymetrix Genome-Wide Human SNP 5.0 Array
Affymetrix Genome-Wide Human SNP 6.0 Array
PacBio RS II
Whole-genome expression profiling in the mouse
Illumina Human Whole-Genome DASL HT
LTQ Orbitrap XL Hybrid Ion Trap-Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer
Illumina HumanMethylation450 BeadChip
Affymetrix Human Gene 1.0 ST Array [transcript (gene) version] in situ oligonucleotide
Affymetrix Human Genome U133 Plus 2.0 Array
Illumina HiSeq X Platform for whole-genome sequencing
Performs whole genome mapping in a nanoscale fluidic environment enabling the structure of the genome to be imaged and then analyzed at the single molecule level
Infinium HumanOmniExpressExome BeadChip
High-throughput sequencing
Infinium Omni2.5Exome-8 v1.3

isCellLine.description: Boolean flag indicating whether or not sample source is a cell line

isPrimaryCell.description: Boolean flag indicating whether or not cellType is primary, defined as 'A cell taken directly from a living organism, which is not immortalized'.

cellType.description: A cell type is a distinct morphological or functional form of cell.

anyOf.description: An adenocarcinoma cell line established by D.J. Giard in 1972 from lung carcinoma tissue removed from a 58-year-old Caucasian male.
A neuron that releases dopamine from its synapses.

A giioblast cell that develops from a migratory neural crest cell. The SCP is embedded among neurons (axons) with minimal extracellular spaces separating them from nerve cell membranes and has no basal lamina. In rodents SCPs are the only cells in the Schwann cell linage that expresses Cdh19.
A lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and surface immunoglobulin-positive.
Embryonic stem (ES) cells are cells derived from the inner cell mass of the early embryo that can be propagated indefinitely in the primitive undifferentiated state while remaining pluripotent.
Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells or iPSCs) are a type of pluripotent stem cell artificially derived from a non-pluripotent cell.
three-dimensional neural cultures (organoids) derived from induced pluripotent stem cells.
A neuron that uses GABA as a vesicular neurotransmitter.
Myeloid mononuclear recirculating leukocyte that can act as a precursor of tissue macrophages, osteoclasts and some populations of tissue dendritic cells.
The small, non-neural, interstitial cells of mesodermal origin that form part of the supporting structure of the central nervous system.

A mononuclear phagocyte present in variety of tissues, typically differentiated from monocytes, capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells.

Astrocytes (from 'star' cells) are irregularly shaped with many long processes, including those with end-feet which form the glial (limiting) membrane and directly and indirectly contribute to the blood-brain barrier.
Human neuroblastoma clonal subline of the neuroepithelioma cell line SK-N-SH that had been established in 1970 from the bone marrow biopsy of a 4-year-old girl with metastatic neuroblastoma.

Have Glutamate receptors, which are synaptic receptors located primarily on the membranes of neuronal cells. Glutamate (the conjugate base of glutamic acid) is abundant in the human body, but particularly in the nervous system and especially prominent in the human brain.

Is a neuronal nuclear antigen that is commonly used as a biomarker for neurons and NeuN immunoreactivity has been widely used to identify neurons in tissue culture to measure the neuron(positive)/glia(negative) ratio in brain regions.

Is a neuronal nuclear antigen that is commonly used as a biomarker for neurons and NeuN immunoreactivity has been widely used to identify neurons in tissue culture to measure the neuron(positive)/glia(negative) ratio in brain regions.
Somatic cells that cover the surface of the body and line its cavities.
In cell morphology, epithelial-like cells are polygonal in shape with more regular dimensions, and grow attached to a substrate in discrete patches.

A connective tissue cell which secretes an extracellular matrix rich in collagen and other macromolecules. Flattened and irregular in outline with branching processes; appear fusiform or spindle-shaped.
A phenotype observation at the level of the cell shape where the cell is round

Often referred to as a blast cell. Unlike other usages of the suffix -blast a lymphoblast is a further differentiation of a lymphocyte, T- or B-, occasioned by an antigenic stimulus. The lymphoblast usually develops by enlargement of a lymphocyte, active re-entry to the S phase of the cell cycle, mitogenesis and production of much m-RNA and ribosomes.
A polygonal face is a polygon bounded by a circuit of polygon edges, and includes the flat (plane) region inside the boundary.
Is a T lymphocyte (a type of white blood cell) that kills cancer cells, cells that are infected (particularly with viruses), or cells that are damaged in other ways.
An arachnoid mater is a delicate membrane that encloses the spinal cord and brain and lies between the pia mater and dura mater.
A central nervous system cancer tissue that are manifested in the central nervous system and arise from the arachnoid 'cap' cells of the arachnoid villi in the meninges.
A neoplasm that arises from SCHWANN CELLS of the cranial, peripheral, and autonomic nerves.
A class of large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system. Form the insulating myelin sheath of axons in the central nervous system.
Schwann cells are a variety of glial cell that keep peripheral nerve fibres (both myelinated and unmyelinated) alive.
Cultured Neuronal cells derived from Olfactory Neuroepithelium

diagnosis.description: A diagnosis is the result of a medical investigation to identify a disorder from its signs and symptoms.

anyOf.description: A genetic syndrome caused by mulitple gene deletions from a region of chromosome 7, and characterized by distinctive facial appearance, mild-to-moderate developmental delay, cheerfulness, cardiovascular abnormalities, and infantile hypercalcemia
A malignancy originating in tissues of the urinary bladder.

A malignant (clonal) hematologic disorder, involving hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by the presence of primitive or atypical myeloid or lymphoid cells in the bone marrow and the blood. Leukemias are classified as acute or chronic based on the degree of cellular differentiation and the predominant cell type present. Leukemia is usually associated with anemia, fever, hemorrhagic episodes, and splenomegaly.
Neurologic disorder manifested particularly by motor and vocal tics and associated with behavioral abnormalities.

(NF1) - A disease characterized by patches of skin pigmentation (cafe-au-lait spots), Lisch nodules of the iris, tumors in the peripheral nervous system and fibromatous skin tumors. Individuals with the disorder have increased susceptibility to the development of benign and malignant tumors.

(NF2) - Genetic disorder characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas (formerly called acoustic neuromas), schwannomas of other cranial and peripheral nerves, meningiomas, and ependymomas. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with full penetrance.
A mood disorder formerly characterised by alternating periods of mania and depression (and in some cases rapid cycling, mixed states, and psychotic symptoms).

(AD) - Alzheimer disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive dementia, loss of cognitive abilities, and deposition of fibrillar amyloid proteins as intraneuronal neurofibrillary tangles, extracellular amyloid plaques and vascular amyloid deposits.
A severe emotional disorder of psychotic depth characteristically marked by a retreat from reality with delusion formation, HALLUCINATIONS, emotional disharmony, and regressive behavior.
An endogenous depression that is characterized by an all-encompassing low mood accompanied by low self-esteem, and by loss of interest or pleasure in normally enjoyable activies.

Wide continuum of associated cognitive and neurobehavioral disorders, including, but not limited to, three core-defining features: impairments in socialization, impairments in verbal and nonverbal communication, and restricted and repetitive patterns of behaviors.
breast fibrocystic disease is a benign mammary displasia characterised by breast discomfort and 'lumpiness'.
(BC) - A common malignancy originating from breast epithelial tissue.
A colorectal cancer that is located_in the colon.
A respiratory system cancer that is located_in the lung.
A male reproductive organ cancer that is located_in the prostate.
An endocrine gland cancer located_in the pancreas.
An integumentary system cancer located_in the skin that is the uncontrolled growth of abnormal skin cells.
A central nervous system cancer that is characterized by the growth of abnormal cells in the tissues of the brain.
An ovarian cancer that is derives_from ovarian surface epithelium.
Change in mood is the main underlying feature of these disorders.

A malignant neoplasm of the cervix, typically originating from a dysplastic or premalignant lesion previously present at the active squamocolumnar junction. The transformation from mild dysplastic to invasive carcinoma generally occurs slowly within several years, although the rate of this process varies widely.

A myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm of childhood that is characterized by proliferation principally of the granulocytic and monocytic lineages. Myelomonocytic proliferation is seen in the bone marrow and the blood. The leukemic cells may infiltrate any tissue, however liver, spleen, lymph nodes, skin, and respiratory tract are the most common sites of involvement.

A movement disease that is characterized by serious and progressive problems with control of gait and balance, along with complex eye movement and thinking problems. It involves gradual deterioration and death of specific volumes of the brain.
Diminished or impaired mental and/or intellectual function.

isMultiIndividual.description: Boolean flag indicating whether or not a file has data for multiple individuals

isMultiSpecimen.description: Boolean flag indicating whether or not a file has data for multiple specimens

sex.description: Sex assigned at birth, or by sequencing

cellLine.description: Identifying string linked to a particular cell line

cellLineSource.description: Identifying source of cell line, such as ATCC site

species.description: The name of a species (typically a taxonomic group) of organism.

anyOf.description: Homo sapiens with taxonomy ID: 9606 and Genbank common name: human

terminalDifferentiationPoint.description: The terminal differentiation point (TD) of a cell in days.

failedQC.description: Boolean flag indicating whether the sample or data failed QC checks
